question.title: {"sections": [{"spans": [{"text": "Is overly aggressive policing in the United States that targets minorities the result of a few bad apples or is it systemic? Can you make an argument for your position on what needs to be done?", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}]}

credentials.translatedString: Assistant Curator at Imperial Valley Desert Museum

answer.content: {"sections": [{"spans": [{"text": "There\u2019s a lot to unpack here.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "\u201cA few bad apples\u201d. This has the common misunderstanding of the phrase, which comes from the fact that \u201ca few bad apples\u201d", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": " literally", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": " cause other apples in the barrel to go bad. It\u2019s often used, as it is here, to imply that the problem is small and limited, but the actual meaning is that the problem", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": " will spread if not addressed", "modifiers": {"bold": true, "italic": true}}, {"text": ". And it has in US police culture. So in a way, yes, it ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "is", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": " the result of \u201ca few bad apples\u201d.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "unordered-list", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "\u201cSystemic\u201d. Yes, the problem is also systemic. This is another term with a lot of confusion surrounding it. \u201cSystemic racism\u201d is often taken to mean \u201c(almost) everyone in the system is racist.\u201d That is", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": " not", "modifiers": {"bold": true}}, {"text": " what it actually means. It means that the system is set up to ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "produce racist outcomes even when the actors in the system are not explicitly racist", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": ".", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "unordered-list", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "There is no question among people who have researched the topic that black communities in the US are over-policed. This is the result of circular reasoning that started with the", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": " presumption", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": " that there is more crime in black (and often in other minority) neighborhoods than in white neighborhoods. This was used as a pretext to put more police in black neighborhoods. When you have more people in an area looking for something, you\u2019re going to find more of it. So the presumption of \u201cmore crime in black neighborhoods\u201d became a self-fulfilling prophecy. And let\u2019s not sugar-coat it: this was ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "the explicit policy", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": " of racists in government using \u201claw and order\u201d rhetoric against black and other minority communities.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "unordered-list", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Coming back to \u201csystemic\u201d, now we have a picture of how the system was put into the state it is by \u201cbad apples\u201d from below and explicitly racist policy decisions from above.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "unordered-list", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Those points are my basic argument for why we need to break down the notion of \u201cpolice\u201d as we have it today in the US and rebuild it. And we should probably plan to revisit that every 20 years or so as society changes and people learn to game the system, which is an inevitable occurrence in any system.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}]}
